ELSEVIER JOURNALOF M ANNULAR CHIALYSIS A; CHEMICAL Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical 118 (1997) L1-L4 Letter Ruthenium- carbene catalysts for the synthesis of 2,3-dimethylfuran Bekir tinkaya a, * , Ismail demir a, Christian Bruneau b, Pierre H. Dixneuf b InUniversity, Faculty of Science and Arts, Department of Chemistry, 44069 Malaya, Turkey b Laboratoire de Chimie de Coordination Organique, URA CNRS 415, Campus de Beaulieu, Universitde Rennes, 35042 Rennes, France Received 4 March 1996; accepted 10 June 1996 Abstract A variety of neutral arene-ruthenium-carbenes of type (arene)RuC12(=C(NR)CH=CH=NR) have been used for the catalytic transformation of (Z)-3-methylpent-2-en-4-yn-l-of into 2,3-dimethylfuran. The catalytic reaction takes place at 80 with mononuclear complexes III-V to afford the furan in - 90% yield. The binuclear catalysts Via and VIIa having a linked bis-carbene bridge operate at room temperature to initiate an exothermic reaction offering 90-97% of furan. Keywords: Ruthenium-carbene catalysts; Activation of Z-enynols; Catalytic synthesis of 2,3-dimethylfuran 1. Introduction Catalytic transformations of alkynes have a potential for developing new methodologies in organic synthesis [1], via formal selective addition to the C=C bond to directly afford unsaturated functional molecules with atom economy [2]. In the recent years several ruthenium complexes were revealed as efficient catalysts to create new carbon-carbon bonds with alkynes as in their dimerization into Z-enynes [3] and butatriene [4] or their coupling with alkenes leading to dimes [5,6] and butenolides, [7] or with allylic alcohols to generate, according to the nature of the catalyst, either a, un- ` Corresponding author. Tel.: +33-99286280; fax: +3399286939. 1381-1169/97/$17.00 Copyright 1997 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved. PIIS1381-1169(96)00239-7 saturated ketones [8] or y,6-unsaturated aldehydes, acetals [9] and ketones [10]. Ruthenium(II) complexes have also been found to promote selective carbon-heteroatom bond formation reactions in the catalytic synthesis of vinyl carbamates [11], enol esters [12a,12, functional dimes [13] and keto esters [14]. Recently, we have found that RuCI,,(PPh3)(arene) and [Ru( /.t,-OZCH)(CO)2(PPh3)]2 complexes could act as catalysts for the activation of (Z)-2-en-4-yn-l-ols toward their intramolecular cyclization into furans [ I S]. The interest of furans in organic synthesis [16] motivated the search for new catalysts favoring this reaction. We now report on the study of a variety of ruthenium-carbene derivatives of type (arene)C1ZRu=C(NR)CH,CH=NR as catalysts for the transformation of ( Z)-3-methylpent-2-en-4-yn- L2 B. tinkaya et al. /Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical 118 (1997) LI-L4 1-01 1 into 2,3-dimethylfuran 2 (Eq. (1)) and we show that binuclear biscarbene complexes are so efficient that the catalytic reaction is initiated at room temperature without solvent and is exothermic. 2. Results and discussion R ~N . H( R R R R N IN ~G RuClz/z + P~C~ R R R "`- J N R - _N~ b 0 a A variety of ruthenium-carbene derivatives III-VII have been prepared from [(arene)RuC12]2 dimers I (arene =p-cymene (a), hexamethylbenzene (b)), by analogy to the cleavage of the chlorobridges by phosphines [ 17], by reaction of the enetetramines II, that are electron-rich olefins [18]. The reaction was shown to generate the cleavage of the C=C bond [19] and the formation of the neutral ruthenium-carbenes III-VII [20] of which the carbene ligand is expected to be a strong o-donor group [21] (Scheme 1). ( Z)-3-methylpent-2-en-4-yn-1-011(10 mmol) (1) was added in a Schlenk tube to 0.1 mmol of Rt arene: p-Me-Q14-'Pr (a) C6Mes (b) II III - VIII ~"-", OMe ~~ OMe (Ru- (Ru- (Ru- N,,,^ OMe 1-1 me Et III a,b IV a,b Va ,Rums -19-< C1 ~ C1 VIa (n=0) VII a (n = 1) EtN,_7-CHz(CHz), CH 2-N, c NEt u Clue ~Cl U Scheme 1. B. etinkaya et al. / Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical 118 (1997) GI -L4 Table 1 Catalytic synthesis of 2,3-dimethylfuran Entry Catalyst T () Time (h) Yield (%) a 18d 19 1 20 `' 21 `' 22 `' 23 d I IIIa Illa 3 Illa 4 IIIb 5 IIIb 6 Illa 7 Illa 8 Illa 9 IIIb 10 IIIb 11 IIIb 12 IVa 13 Iva 14 Ivb 15 IVb 16 Va 17 Va V la VIa VIa VIa VIIa VIIa 60 60 60 60 60 80 80 80 80 80 80 80 80 80 80 80 80 r.t. ` r.t. r.t. ` r.t. ` r. t. r.t. ` 1.5 2.5 16.5 1 6.5 1 2.25 3.7 1 3.4 3.75 1 2 1 2.25 1 2 1 2 6 21 0.2 1 44 60 87 (7s> b 60 83 (75) b 79 87 90 (82) b 67 88 89 (83) b 87 92 (as> b ao 90 (85) b 74 92 (82> b 49 50 84 95 (83) b 87 97 Reaction conditions: To 0.1 mmol of ruthenium catalyst III-V were added 10 mmol of (Z)-3-methylpent-2-en-4-yn-l-of without additional solvent. The mixture was stirred in an oil bath at 60 -80 for 1-20 h. The reaction with 0.05 mmol of catalysts VIa and VIIa was performed starting at room temperature. Yield measured using gas chromatography. b Isolated yield after distillation. ` The stirring at 22 led to an exothermic reaction. d 0.05 mmol of complex. ruthenium complexes III-V without any additional solvent and the mixture was stirred at 60-80 in an oil bath for 1-20 h. The conversion of 1 was monitored by gas chromatography and led to the formation of only one product, the colorless 2,3-dimethylfuran 2 (Eq. (1)) which was identified by spectroscopy [ 15]. (2: 1 H NMR (300 MHz, CDC13) 8 (ppm): 1.94 and 2.19 (s, Me), 6.14 and 7.19 (d, CH=, 3JHH = 1.8 Hz), IR (film) v(c -cl = 1605 cm-'.) The results are summarized in Table 1. They show that the ruthenium-carbene complexes III-V are good catalysts for the transformation of 1 into 2 above 60. The best yields were obtained at 80 for 1-3 h (entries 6 and 9, 10 as compared to entries 1 and 4, respectively). It is noteworthy that the catalysts IIIb and IVb containing the hexamethylbenzene ligands are more efficient at 60 than IIIa and IVa containing the p-cymene group, as the conversion of 1 is faster (entries 4 and 5 as compared to entries 1 and 3). This difference in behavior is no longer worthy to note at 80. This is attributed to the easiness of displacement of the arene ligand which is observed by gas chromatography, and is supposed to be the key step generating the active ruthenium species from (arene)RuC12(PR3) [12b]. The comparison of catalysts III and IV indicates that complexes IV containing only one coordinating `arm' linked to the nitrogen atoms are more efficient (entries: 6, 12 and 9, 14). Complex Va bearing no coordinating arms attached to the carbene ligand appeared to be also an efficient catalyst, as 92% yield of 2 were formed (entry 17). Thus, the catalysts III-V in an average of 2-3 h at 80 could afford 90% of furan 2 which was isolated in 80-85% yields after distillation (entries: 8, 11, 13, 15, 17). The catalytic efficiency of complexes III-V is comparable to that of RuC12(PR 3)(arene) complexes [15] which can even operate at 60. Attempts to carry out the same transformation 1 - 2 with the complexes VIa and VIIa having their carbene units linked by a NCH ZCH 2-N (VIa) or N-CH ZCH ZCH 2-N bridge (VIIa) led to the observation that the reaction did not require any heating. Actually, starting from room temperature, the stirring of 0.05 mmol of the binuclear complex into 10 mmol of the enynol 1 led to an exothermic reaction. With complex VIa the stirring at 22 for 21 h afforded 95% yield of 2 (83% isolated) (entry 21). Under similar conditions, the stirring of catalyst VIIa in enynol 1 led to an exothermic reaction bringing the reaction mixture to the boil. The reaction was almost completed after 10 min and a 97% yield of 2 was reached after 1 h (entries 22, 23). The above reaction represents a new example of metal complexes of N-heterocyclic carbenes in catalysis. The first example has just been L4 B. tinkaya et al. /Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical 118 (1997) LI-L4 described to promote the Heck reaction in the presence of imidazole derivative carbene-palladium catalysts [22]. No proof can be brought to explain the efficiency of catalysts VIa and VIIa, which are by far the best catalysts for the formation of furan 2 with respect to complexes III-V or RuCIZ(PR3)(arene) [15]. However, the suggestion can be made that their p-cymene ligand can be lost, as observed by gas chromatography, much more easily than from the mononuclear complexes, thus generating an active coordinatively unsaturated ruthenium species able to activate the triple bond of the enynol. Dixneuf b a Inönü University, Faculty of Science and Arts, Department of Chemistry, 44069 Malatya, Turkey b Laboratoire de Chimie de Coordination Organique, URA CNRS 415, Campus de Beaulieu, Université de Rennes, 35042 Rennes, France ∗ Corresponding author. Tel.: +33-99286280; fax: +33-99286939. A variety of neutral arene-ruthenium-carbenes of type (arene)RuCl2(= C(NR)CH2CH2N R) have been used for the catalytic transformation of (Z)-3-methylpent-2-en-4-yn-1-ol into 2,3-dimethylfuran. The catalytic reaction takes place at 80°C with mononuclear complexes III–V to afford the furan in ∼ 90% yield. The binuclear catalysts VIa and VIIa having a linked bis-carbene bridge operate at room temperature to initiate an exothermic reaction offering 90–97% of furan. coredata.dc:description: A variety of neutral arene-ruthenium-carbenes of type (arene)RuCl2(= C(NR)CH2CH2N R) have been used for the catalytic transformation of (Z)-3-methylpent-2-en-4-yn-1-ol into 2,3-dimethylfuran. The catalytic reaction takes place at 80°C with mononuclear complexes III–V to afford the furan in ∼ 90% yield. The binuclear catalysts VIa and VIIa having a linked bis-carbene bridge operate at room temperature to initiate an exothermic reaction offering 90–97% of furan.
